sections.text: Mina Park: Hi Ricardo—Mina Park here. Thanks for taking a few minutes. I’ll keep it brief: I work with teams who are trying to get really crisp on which customer segments are actually worth targeting, and why.
Ricardo Alvarez: Hey Mina, sure—what are you calling about?

Mina Park: I’m reaching out because we built a product called Customer_Analyzer. It pulls together the signals you already have—CRM fields, onboarding surveys, product usage, support tickets, even interview notes—and turns that into a simple, defensible “who should we go after next” answer. I noticed Vividcedar Marketing has been expanding campaigns across a few verticals, and I’m guessing prioritization is getting harder.
Ricardo Alvarez: Yeah, that’s fair. We’re testing a couple industries and it’s not always clear what’s best, beyond lead volume.

Mina Park: Exactly. Lead volume is usually the loudest signal, but not the most profitable one. The core output we focus on is a fit score—0 to 100—at the account and segment level. Then we show the driver breakdown, so it’s not a black box: “Here’s why mid-market healthcare scores higher than SMB retail,” for example, based on retention, support burden, time-to-value, and adoption patterns.
Ricardo Alvarez: Interesting. How do you get those inputs? We have pieces of that, but it’s spread out.

Mina Park: That’s the normal starting point. Customer_Analyzer ingests from your CRM and support system first—because those are fast wins—then you can layer in product usage events if you have them, and any structured survey data. The key is you define the fit drivers you care about—industry, size, problem severity, support burden, churn risk—and we compute the score per segment, plus a segment comparison view.
Ricardo Alvarez: When you say “support burden,” what do you mean? Ticket volume?

Mina Park: Ticket volume is one piece, but we usually normalize it. Like: tickets per active account, time-to-resolution, escalations, and the categories of issues. Some segments generate a lot of “how do I use this” tickets early and then stabilize; others keep generating complex issues. Customer_Analyzer uses those trends as signals when it estimates fit.
Ricardo Alvarez: Okay. Our challenge is that some industries look good up front but end up taking tons of support later, and it kills margins.

Mina Park: That’s a perfect use case. One common workflow is: “Prioritize which industries to target next quarter using retention and support burden signals.” So instead of deciding based on pipeline alone, you can answer: which industries convert well *and* renew well *and* don’t overload support. The output is a recommended ICP profile based on observed outcomes—retention, expansion, conversion.
Ricardo Alvarez: We do quarterly planning now and it’s a lot of debate. People bring anecdotes, not evidence.

Mina Park: Right—and that’s exactly where the driver breakdown helps. If the score says “72,” we show the “why”: strong adoption patterns, low support burden, fast time-to-value, and low churn risk signals. Or the opposite: good conversion, but poor retention and high support cost. That way the conversation changes from opinions to trade-offs.
Ricardo Alvarez: How long does it take to get to something usable? I’m not looking for a six-month analytics project.

Mina Park: Totally. We aim for a quick first pass—usually a couple weeks to connect data sources and define fit drivers, then you have initial segment scoring. After that, teams iterate: add another driver, refine definitions, or split segments differently. But you’re not waiting months to see value.
Ricardo Alvarez: And how do the segments get defined—do we define them or does the system?

Mina Park: You can do either. Most teams start with how they already think: industry, company size, maybe geography or a key use case. Customer_Analyzer will compare those segments side-by-side. Then, based on outcomes, it can recommend a tighter ICP definition—for example, “mid-market manufacturing with high onboarding survey severity and fast activation,” if that’s what correlates with retention and expansion.
Ricardo Alvarez: That’s helpful. We have CRM data pretty clean, but product usage is… not perfect.

Mina Park: That’s okay. The fit estimation isn’t dependent on perfect event tracking. If you have any proxy for adoption—logins, activation milestones, feature usage—it helps, but you can get a lot from CRM + support + retention outcomes alone. We also show confidence by driver, so you know what’s solid versus what’s inferred.
Ricardo Alvarez: What would you need from us to sanity-check whether this would work?

Mina Park: For a quick evaluation, I’d ask for: (1) your current segmentation—what industries you’re debating for next quarter, (2) the retention or churn outcomes by account for the last 12–18 months, and (3) support ticket volume and resolution time by account. With that, we can run a lightweight fit estimation model and show you a segment comparison: where you’re getting the best retention with the lowest support burden.
Ricardo Alvarez: And that’s something you can show on a call?

Mina Park: Yes. The next step I’d suggest is a 30–45 minute working session. You can bring whoever owns planning—maybe someone from ops or product marketing—and we’ll map your fit drivers, then I’ll show you what the output looks like: the fit score per segment, the breakdown, and what an ICP recommendation would look like for Vividcedar.
Ricardo Alvarez: I like the idea. My only concern is change management—our team is used to deciding based on pipeline and gut feel.

Mina Park: That’s common. The way we position it internally is: we’re not replacing pipeline thinking, we’re adding “quality of revenue” signals—retention and support burden—so your next-quarter bet doesn’t create next-year churn. And because the model is explainable, it’s easier to get buy-in. People can disagree with a driver, adjust it, and see the impact.
Ricardo Alvarez: Makes sense. Do you integrate with HubSpot? That’s our CRM.

Mina Park: Yes—HubSpot is straightforward for the CRM portion. For support, we can connect to the major ticketing tools, and if you have anything custom, we can start with exports. The goal is to get you a segment-level view quickly, not boil the ocean.
Ricardo Alvarez: Alright. If we do the working session, what would “success” look like by the end of it?

Mina Park: By the end, you’d have: your fit drivers defined, your top segments scored with an initial fit score, and a clear view of what’s driving those scores—especially retention and support burden. Ideally you walk away with a short list like: “Target these two industries next quarter, deprioritize this one, and here’s the evidence.”
Ricardo Alvarez: That would be really useful for planning. Can we do next week?
Mina Park: Absolutely. I have Tuesday at 11am or Thursday at 2pm—either work?
Ricardo Alvarez: Thursday at 2pm works. Send an invite.

Mina Park: Perfect. I’ll send the calendar invite for Thursday at 2pm, and I’ll include a short list of what to bring—HubSpot segment fields, churn/retention outcomes, and support ticket metrics. Looking forward to it, Ricardo.
Ricardo Alvarez: Sounds good. Thanks Mina—talk then.
